law.text:
As used in KRS 158.830 to 158.836:
"Anaphylaxis" means an allergic reaction resulting from sensitization following prior contact with an antigen which can be a life-threatening emergency. Anaphylaxis may be triggered by, among other agents, foods, drugs, injections, insect stings, and physical activity.
"Medications" means all medicines individually prescribed by a health care practitioner for the student that pertain to his or her asthma or used to treat anaphylaxis, including but not limited to EpiPen or other auto-injectible epinephrine;
"Health care practitioner" means a physician or other health care provider who has prescriptive authority; and
"Self-administration" means the student's use of his or her prescribed asthma or anaphylaxis medications, pursuant to prescription or written direction from the health care practitioner.
law.history: Amended 2004 Ky. Acts ch. 132, sec. 5, effective April 21, 2004. -- Created 2002 Ky. Acts ch. 50, sec. 2, effective July 15, 2002.
